verses.text: See, you are beautiful, my love; you are beautiful! Your eyes are like doves behind your veil. Your hair is like a flock of goats streaming down from Mount Gilead.
verses.comment: The imagery of doves and the veil represents purity and mystery, reflecting both human love and the hidden beauty of the soul seeking God. The poetic comparison to goats descending Mount Gilead draws on pastoral imagery familiar in ancient Israel.

verses.text: Your teeth are like a flock of newly shorn sheep coming up from the washing, each bearing twins, not one among them is bereaved.
verses.comment: This imagery emphasizes fullness and perfection — none are missing. Spiritually, it evokes the redeemed community marked by unity and wholeness, echoed in images of spiritual rebirth.

verses.text: Your lips are like a scarlet thread, and your mouth is lovely. Your cheeks behind your veil are like slices of pomegranate.
verses.comment: Red lips and blushing cheeks convey beauty, purity, and joyful speech. In biblical tradition, fruitful speech and the heart’s purity point to the believer's participation in divine life.

verses.text: Your neck is like the tower of David, built with courses of stone; on it hang a thousand shields, all shields of mighty men.
verses.comment: The tower of David is symbolic of strength and dignity, paralleling the steadfastness of faith. The shields suggest both protection and honorable adornment, echoing the virtues upheld within the believing community.

verses.text: Your two breasts are like two fawns, twins of a gazelle grazing among the lilies.
verses.comment: The imagery here is delicate and tender, highlighting innocence and natural beauty. In traditional interpretation, this also points to spiritual nourishment offered by wisdom and truth, in the midst of purity symbolized by lilies.

verses.text: Until the day breathes and the shadows flee, I will go to the mountain of myrrh and to the hill of frankincense.
verses.comment: Mountains of myrrh and hills of frankincense call to mind offerings and prayer, echoing Christ's later birth gifts and sacrificial imagery. The spiritual ascent here points toward communion with God, developing intimacy through prayer and sacrifice.

verses.text: You are altogether beautiful, my love; there is no flaw in you.
verses.comment: This perfect beauty prefigures the spotless bride imagery used in Christ’s relationship with the Church. The reference supports the understanding of holiness and sanctification as key to union with God.

verses.text: Come with me from Lebanon, my bride, come with me from Lebanon. Depart from the peak of Amana, from the peak of Senir and Hermon, from the dens of lions, from the mountains of leopards.
verses.comment: Invitation to leave dangerous places suggests leaving behind worldly dangers to embrace union with the beloved. 'Bride' here is a profound image of covenant—echoing the relationship between God and his people, ultimately fulfilled in the one, visible apostolic Church.

verses.text: You have captivated my heart, my sister, my bride; you have captivated my heart with a single glance of your eyes, with a single strand of your necklace.
verses.comment: The affectionate language deepens intimacy, underscoring the dignity granted to the bride through loving union. The spiritual reading sees this as God’s tender love for the faithful soul.

verses.text: How delightful is your love, my sister, my bride! How much better than wine is your love, and the fragrance of your ointments surpasses all spices.
verses.comment: The surpassing sweetness of love and the fragrance of ointments associate spiritual love and sacrifice with joy and spiritual delight, similar to sacramental grace and holy living.

verses.text: Your lips drip honey, my bride; honey and milk are under your tongue. The scent of your garments is like the fragrance of Lebanon.
verses.comment: Honey and milk invoke the promised land (Ex. 3:8) and the sweetness of spiritual wisdom. The association with garments points to outward signs of inward grace, reminiscent of holy attire.

verses.text: A garden locked is my sister, my bride, a spring locked, a fountain sealed.
verses.comment: A sealed garden conveys exclusivity, sanctity, and purity—often understood as referring to the spiritual purity and sacramental life of the faithful, reserved wholly for divine fellowship.

verses.text: Your sprays are an orchard of pomegranates with precious fruits: henna and nard,
verses.comment: The orchard represents spiritual fruitfulness and richness of the soul. The precious fruits echo the manifold virtues and works pleasing to God.

verses.text: nard and saffron, calamus and cinnamon, with all trees of frankincense, myrrh and aloes, with all the finest spices.
verses.comment: These aromatic plants and spices were used in worship and anointing. Their abundance signals an overflowing blessing and hints at the sacramental nature of worship.

verses.text: A garden fountain, a well of living water, flowing from Lebanon.
verses.comment: Living water echoes Christ’s words about the gift of the Spirit and the soul’s refreshment in Him. Lebanon’s significance evokes purity and sustenance, pointing toward the sacramental source of divine grace flowing to believers.

verses.text: Awake, north wind, and come, south wind! Blow upon my garden, let its spices flow. Let my beloved come to his garden, and eat its choicest fruits.
verses.comment: The call for winds to awaken the garden symbolizes the action of the Spirit stirring the soul. The union between the beloved and the garden portrays profound communion, both individually and corporately within the Church as the mystical body of Christ, drawing believers into deeper sacramental life and spiritual intimacy.
